net.floodlightcontroller.nbextension
Class ControllerSupport

java.lang.Object
  net.floodlightcontroller.nbextension.ControllerSupport
All Implemented Interfaces:
net.floodlightcontroller.core.module.IFloodlightModule, INBExtension
public class ControllerSupport
extends java.lang.Object
implements net.floodlightcontroller.core.module.IFloodlightModule, INBExtension

Northbound API controller support extension.

Configuration Parameters

Note: The parameters listed in the table below must be prefaced in the floodlight configuration file with the string that identifies parameters for the floodlight module instance (class) that will provide the service.

Configuration Parameter Name Data Type Default Description
"UseRoutingDataForGetIPAddrInfo" boolean true Determines if routing table data will be used by the "GetIPAddrInfo" function to determine the actual IP address to be looked up. If true, the gateway address (if present) will be used for the first matching table entry.

Protocol description

extensionType = 'ControllerSupport'

In the following table, the "request" and "reply" portions describe the content stored in the value element (of type ValuePB) in the NBExtensionPB protocol buffer message element. Also, by convention, these descriptions will use brackets ("[]") to enclose arrays of values and braces ("{}") to enclose a string-to-value map. 

 request: {'request' = '<FunctionList>'}
 reply:   [ String ]
 description:
Returns list of supported request names.

 request: {'request' = 'MACAddrForSwitchIPAddr', 'dpid' = anInt64, 'ipV4Addr' = anInt32}
 reply:   [ anInt64 ] or -null-

 request: {'request' = 'SwitchPortForMACAddr',   'dpid' = anInt64, 'macAddr'  = anInt64}
 reply:   anInt32 or -null-

 request: {'request' = 'NextTransactionID',      'dpid' = anInt64}
 reply:   anInt32 or -null- if dpid is unknown
   or
 request: {'request' = 'NextTransactionID',      'dpid' = anInt64, 'count'    = anInt32}
 reply:   [ anInt32 ] or -null- if dpid is unknown or count exceeds NextTransactionID_CountLimit

 request: {'request' = 'PriorityRange'}
 reply:   {'startPriority' = anInt32, 'endPriority' = anInt32}

 request: {'request' = 'SendARP',                'dpid' = anInt64, 'ipV4Addr' = anInt32, 'inPort' = anInt32}
 reply:   -null- on success or false if dpid is unknown or an I/O error occurred

 request: {'request' = 'GetIPAddrInfo', 'ipV4Addr' = anInt32, 'ARP' = anInt32,
           'dpid' = anInt64, 'switchPort' = anInt32, 'exPort' = anInt32}
 reply:   [{'macAddr' = anInt64, 'dpid' = anInt64, 'switchPort' = anInt32,
            'age' = anInt64, 'forGateway' = anInt32}]
          (an array of maps)
 description:
Gets all host device information for a specified IPv4 address from the controller device look-up data after optionally sending an ARP request. ARP, dpid, swPort, and exPort are optional in the request. ARP defaults to zero; if greater than zero (milliseconds) an ARP is only sent if the controller has not sent an ARP for the specified IPv4 address within a controller configuration-defined time interval (for that datapath ID switch/port). On receipt of the message, the controller will wait
(last ARP sent time + ARP time) - now
milliseconds before returning results from controller device look-up. If no datapath ID is specified, all known datapath IDs are used. Either swPort or exPort (not both) may only be specified if dpid is specified. swPort further constrains the results and ARPs to that specific physical switch port (value MUST be in physical port range). exPort defines the physical exclusion port (all ports except this one) when sending ARPs to all ports on a switch (value MUST be in physical port range). The return age is the difference (in milliseconds) between the device's 'lastSeen' time with the controller's current time (to avoid clock-drift issues between client and controller). When sending an ARP to more than one port on a switch, a broadcast is used rather than sending the ARPs individually to a subset of ports. This is the only case where an ARP may be sent to a port (by this path) earlier than the ARP suppression logic would otherwise allow.

If the "UseRoutingDataForGetIPAddrInfo" setting is true (the default) the IPv4 routing table for each datapath ID is consulted. If there is a matching entry and the entry has a gateway address, the link-layer (MAC) address, switch port, and age data will be returned for the gateway IPv4 address rather than the requested IP address. As with the 'IPv4RoutingTableNotify' function, currently active device data will take precedence over any configured IPv4 routing table values. When information for a gateway address is returned, the 'forGateway' parameter will contain the IPv4 address of the gateway. In all other cases the value will be zero.

Note: The current implementation blocks while waiting: thus, the client reader thread is blocked and will not process any requests during the ARP wait time. 

 request: {'request' = 'SwPortChangeNotify', 'macAddr' = anInt64, 'dpid' = anInt64, 'enable' = boolean}
 replies: {'event' = 'SwPortChangeNotify', 'macAddr' = anInt64, 'dpid' = anInt64, 'enabled' = boolean,
           'switchPort' = anInt32}
 description:
Registers for switch-port change notification. On receipt of a request (regardless of "enable" value), the current switch-port information for the specified MAC address (and dpid) is returned immediately in a reply "event" message. If the specified MAC address is not known to be associated with any port for the dpid, the switch port value returned will be OFPP_NONE. If dpid is unknown/invalid, the reply event will have a switch port of OFPP_NONE and "enabled" will be false. When "enable" is true and a subsequent switch-port change is detected for the specified MAC address, a reply "event" message is asynchronously generated and sent to the client. If "enable" is false and there is no current registration for the specified MAC address, the current switch-port information is returned (not an error). All replies will cary the requestID of the most recent request message with the specified MAC address (and dpid). The request is considered invalid if the MAC address is zero or has the broadcast bit set. If a subsequent request for a given MAC address and dpid is received with a different request ID, then a "final" reply event is generated using the prior request ID with "enabled" set to false.

 request: {'request' = 'IPv4RoutingTableNotify', 'dpid' = anInt64, 'enable' = boolean, 'ARP' = anInt32}
 replies: {'event' = 'IPv4RoutingTableNotify', 'dpid' = anInt64, 'enabled' = boolean,
           'ipv4Table' = [{'dest' = anInt32, 'mask' = anInt32, gateway-data}]}
 gateway-data:  'gateway' = anInt32, 'macAddr' = anInt64, 'switchPort' = anInt32
 description:
Registers for IPv4 routing table change notification. On receipt of a request (regardless of the enable value), the current IPv4 routing table information for the specified dpid is returned immediately in a reply "event" message. If dpid is unknown/invalid, or the client has no access to routing table information associated with the dpid, then the reply event will have an error status and the table will be empty. The table may be empty with no error status if the client has access to routing table information for the dpid but there currently isn't any (e.g., passive learning from DHCP or other routing protocols has yet to see any relevant packets). Each generated "event" message will contain a full table for the time at which the message was created and will carry the request ID of the most recent enable request for that dpid. If no gateway-data is provided in a table entry, then that entry's destination/mask network exists for the LAN segment containing the switch. If a subsequent request for a given dpid is received with a different request ID, then a "final" reply event is generated using the prior request ID with "enabled" set to false. An event will only be generated if a new routing table entry is added or an existing entry is removed -- specifically, no event is generated if the MAC or switch-port information changes for the gateway address. The gateway MAC or switch-port is only provided if known at the time the "event" message is generated, and currently active device data will take precedence over any configured values.

As with GetIPAddrInfo, the ARP parameter defaults to zero and, if greater than zero (milliseconds), an ARP is sent for any gateway host for which link-layer (MAC) address or switch-port information is not currently available and, after all ARPs have been sent, waits the specified time before attempting to retreive the information from the local device tables. If the link-layer (MAC) address or switch-port information is not available, those elements will not be added to the reply map for the routing table gateway entry. The ARP parameter only affects the initial request, not the subsequent asynchronous reply events. The ARP time is capped at one minute.
